newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-AMLC Beef Weekly - Australian export prices.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-AMLC Beef Weekly - Australian export prices.

text.p: Australian Meat and Livestock Corp's (AMLC) weekly export prices are as follows:
AUSTRALIAN EXPORT PRICES TO U.S. IN U.S. CENTS/LB, CIF.
Bull (95 Chemical Lean) 83 +2 on last week
Shank (90 CL) 77 +2
Trimmings (85 CL) 74 +2
Chucks (85 CL) 75 -1
AUSTRALIAN EXPORT PRICES TO JAPAN IN U.S. CENTS/LB CIF.
Chilled grassfed fullsets 142 -3 on last week
Chilled grassfed loin:striploin 240 +3
cube roll 293 -3
tender loin 515 +6
Frozen Chuck/blade 92 -1
Frozen Thick flank 103 +1
Frozen Fore/hind blended 80 -1
Frozen Topside 107 n/c
Frozen Silverside 94 -3
Frozen Brisket 87 -1
AMLC COMMENTARY: The rain proved beneficial for cattle markets this week, restricting supplies and forcing prices much higher than those endured througout most of January.
Excellent rainfall fell across vast areas of central and northern New South Wales and most of central Queensland.
Many areas on the coast were deluged with rainfall in excess of 150mm during the week.
This should assist markets in the short term by reducing offerings in New South Wales and Queensland and providing restocker competition from these states in Victorian markets.
Extremely cold weather in the U.S. mid section continued to cause concern. This prolonged difficult weather has reduced cow supplies considerably.

This has been a primary factor in last week's price increases for lean grinding meat, as cow prices have risen significantly. A second important influence on the grinding beef sector at present is a relative shortage of frozen lean meat supplies.
The retailer ground beef business remains more subdued than a few weeks ago, but is still described as good. The foodservice business on the other hand remains mediocre.
Trading activity for imported beef was slow until midweek and offerings were light to moderate.
U.S. domestic boneless beef prices rose sharply on Wednesday and imported prices followed.
As the table indicates ,prices for Australian grinding beef in general rose 2-2.25 USc/lb. Market participants reported user activity as weak, which is usual during this time.
Trader interest appeared to be covering short positions and was very active on both Wednesday and Thursday (U.S. time).
Supplies of imported lean grinding beef for spot delivery appeared limited this week.
In the Japanese market, developments this week were dominated by the continued weakening of the yen against the US$.
The current rate (US$1.00=122 yen) is the highest level the US$ has reached against the yen since February 1993.
The rate reached US$1=85 in mid-1995 and has since drifted out of Japan's favour.
The weakening of this rate in effect makes imported beef more expensive to Japanese traders, as a greater number of yen is required to purchase one US$, the currency in which beef is traded in Japan.
It will be very interesting to see the effects of the current cold snap on January placement levels.
If movements into feedlots are again low during January, U.S. supplies could begin to tighten from April onwards.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
